extractions.extraction_text: Nominal values can only distinguish one object from another. Examples: Zip code, Political preferences, Genres.

attributes.definition: Values that can only distinguish one object from another.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Data that can be named or labeled but cannot be ordered or measured numerically. Think of categories like 'red' or 'blue'.

extractions.extraction_text: like zip code, like your name, right? My name is Shin Chen. I can only find the person who having the same name with me or not the same name.

attributes.summary_of_example: Names and zip codes are examples of nominal data because they are used to identify and distinguish individuals or locations, not for mathematical operations.

extractions.extraction_text: For example, zip code I am having some one like if they are from 90201, which means they are more, uh, the company, they actually start earlier. If that is the cases, you need to find another feature to indicate that or actually convert that feature into something.

attributes.summary_of_insight: If a nominal feature (like zip code) appears to have an order or numerical meaning, it might need to be converted or a new feature created to represent its true categorical nature.

extractions.extraction_text: Nominal data again. If you try to do, uh, the nominal data you need to set it as categorical data. Okay. English. And usually they will only give you two choice. One is called categorical data. One another is called number.

attributes.summary_of_insight: Nominal data should be treated as categorical data, not numerical, even if it looks like a number.

extractions.extraction_text: So right now the vehicle is look like 0, not 30013. It look like number, but you shouldn't set it as number. You shouldn't set it as numerical data. You need to set them as string or you set them as nominal data, depends on what kind of thing. So if you do not find categorical data, set them as a string. Because string can also only do equal and not equal.

attributes.summary_of_insight: Represent nominal data as strings or a specific nominal/categorical type in your system, as these types only support equality checks, reflecting the nature of nominal data.

extractions.extraction_text: For example, you can only do equal and not equal.

attributes.summary_of_insight: The primary operations for analyzing nominal data are checking for equality or inequality.

extractions.extraction_text: So you can find a distribution. Or you can find who are the county have the majority of the people. Something like that, mode.

attributes.definition: Mode is the value that appears most frequently in a data set. Distribution refers to how data is spread or arranged.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Mode tells you the most common item in a list. Distribution shows you how often different items appear.

extractions.extraction_text: So for example, like this one, uh, attribute. And why axis, what will be the number of the people involved with this zip code. So for example, this one are 90007. This one are 90201. So for example, this is attribute. And the mode will be, oh, see right here is the one have the biggest number right here. So that is the mode.

attributes.summary_of_example: Illustrates finding the mode by showing zip codes on the x-axis and the number of people on the y-axis, identifying the zip code with the highest number of people as the mode.

extractions.extraction_text: And the distribution is also one very important way for us to, uh, understand our data. When you try to do the, uh, final project at the very beginning, you might need to do a lot of distribution.

attributes.summary_of_insight: Understanding data distribution is crucial for initial data analysis, especially in projects.

extractions.extraction_text: Ordinal values can help to order objects.

attributes.definition: Ordinal values can help to order objects.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Ordinal data represents categories that have a natural order, like 'small', 'medium', 'large'.

text:

## Video Segment: 84:03 - 88:01

[SLIDE DESCRIPTION]
Nominal values can only distinguish one object from another. Examples: Zip code, Political preferences, Genres. How to analyze?
